data.title: Moving to Tacoma, WA – Best Place to Live in the U.S. in 2024
data.meta_description: Moving to Tacoma, WA? Livability helps people find their best places to live, work and play. Find out why Tacoma is a best place to live.
data.text:
Tacoma, WABest Places to Live in the U.S. in 2024

Located along the shores of the Puget Sound, Tacoma’s stunning waterfront views, diverse neighborhoods and revitalized downtown district contribute to the high quality of life here. Tacoma residents have access to an affordable lifestyle and plenty of things to do.

Home > Washington > Tacoma, WA

Tacoma, WA

Why You’ll Love Living in Tacoma, Washington

Tacoma, Washington, might be the perfect place for outdoorsy people to call home. It’s more affordable and less congested than neighboring Seattle and still offers residents some incredible amenities, including a spectacular assortment of museums and a world-class arts scene that encompasses professional ballet, opera and orchestra organizations. It boasts one of the best park systems in the country, including Point Defiance Park and the beautiful Owen Beach on the Puget Sound. Mt. Rainier National Park is just an hour away. Job opportunities are plentiful in industries including finance, insurance, government, aerospace and retail.

Thinking of moving to Tacoma, Washington? Keep scrolling to find all the details about living in Tacoma, including quick facts such as the population, median home value and property taxes. Plus, learn more about the cost of living and quality of life in Tacoma, from the economy and job opportunities to weather, outdoor activities and things to do, including local restaurants and points of interest.

What Makes Tacoma, WA, a Best Place to Live in 2024

Urban sophistication comes to mind when you talk about Tacoma, WA, ranked as one of the best places to live in the U.S. As the state’s second-largest city, Tacoma is located on Puget Sound (Seattle is just across the Sound) and surrounded by the Pacific Northwest’s magnificent natural beauty. That grandeur affords opportunities to explore the outdoors, with activities like fishing, biking, hiking, golfing, swimming and boating. There are also more than 80 parks and recreational areas, which include more than 8 miles of beaches and shoreline. All of that splendor means Tacoma residents are passionate about the environment and minimizing their impact on these important ecosystems. That idea trickles down to providing green transportation, affordable housing and more.

Indoor pursuits include museums like the well-known Museum of Glass, where you can see artists in action and take in the Chihuly Bridge of Glass, the famous pedestrian walkway by famed glass artist and Tacoma native Dale Chihuly. The Tacoma Art Museum and America’s Car Museum are two of Tacoma’s other cultural offerings.

The metro’s public schools definitely make the grade. For those looking for higher education options, there’s the University of Washington Tacoma and liberal arts schools such as Pacific Lutheran University and the University of Puget Sound. Plus, the city has an array of incredible restaurants, fun shops and live music venues that attract students and residents alike.

Finally, Tacoma’s stable economy makes it a no-brainer as a place to put down roots, with diverse industries such as health care, logistics, aerospace and technology.

Tacoma ranks highest for environment, amenities and economy.

Education56

Environment: minimize natural disaster risk, have good air quality and reasonable population density. Sample metrics: Earthquake Risk, Climate Suitability Subscore

Health57

Health: positive health outcomes and easy access to excellent healthcare. Sample metrics: Life Expectancy, Doctor & Hospital Access

Housing & Cost of Living55

Housing & Cost of Living: relatively affordable housing for renters and owners, reasonable taxes and an overall modest cost of living. Sample metrics: Tax Rates, Percent Below Poverty Level, Rental & Home Affordability Ratios

Safety35

Safety: relatively low crime rates. Sample metrics: Murder, Larceny

Transportation57

Transportation: drivable, walkable, bikeable and more with short commutes. Samplemetrics: Multimodal Intersection Density, Vehicles Per Household

Weather and Outdoor Activities in Tacoma, WA

What is the weather like in Tacoma?

While the Pacific Northwest is often known as a rainy region, Tacoma experiences less rain than its counterparts. The city has a marine West Coast climate, experiencing cool to mild temperatures year-round and relatively consistent yearly precipitation. The average highs and lows are 73°F and 53°F (summer) and 47°F and 35°F (winter).

Does Tacoma get a lot of snow?

The average annual snowfall in Tacoma is relatively low; the city only receives an average of less than 3 inches a year.

Does Tacoma get a lot of rain?

The average annual rainfall in Tacoma is around 40 inches, and it is pretty evenly distributed throughout the year.

How many sunny days does Tacoma get?

Tacoma averages 144 sunny days a year.

What are some things to do outside in Tacoma?

Explore Point Defiance Park, a local gem with walking trails, gardens and scenic waterfront views. The park is free to wander, but you’ll have to pay for specific attractions, such as the Point Defiance Zoo & Aquarium. While there are multiple dog-friendly patios and plenty of enjoyable dog parks in Tacoma, it really all does come back to Point Defiance. Its off-leash area is a staggering 7 acres, fenced off from the roadway and waterfront bluff. Plus, there’s also a smaller fenced area for pups.

Things To Do in Tacoma, WA

What is something free to do in Tacoma?

Pack a picnic and set up shop on the large green space at Browns Point Lighthouse Park to enjoy scenic water views and the lighthouse. Nearby Ruston Way has a beautiful 2-mile path with views of the water, where you can walk, jog, fish and more.

What are some fun things to do with kids in Tacoma?

Bring your quarters to Dorky’s Bar Arcade, where gamers of all ages can play an assortment of 1980s-era pinball machines and video games.

What is the best open secret about Tacoma?

Tacoma has an inspiring artsy side. Dale Chihuly, arguably the most famous glass artist on the planet, was born in Tacoma. Make sure to plan a trip to the Museum of Glass, the largest and most interactive museum glass studio on the entire West Coast. Located on the water, right in downtown – which includes a handful of other great art museums – the acclaimed gallery offers live glass-blowing demonstrations, powerful exhibitions, and unique DIY glass experiences.

Where do locals shop in Tacoma?

Shop local! You can find locally owned shops all over the city. King’s Books is the spot to find a fabulous new or used read. Grab an afternoon pick-me-up at Bluebeard Coffee Roasters, where you can sample a La Pistola Mexican Mocha, a spicy chocolate sauce that tastes a bit like a molé.

Where is the best place for dinner in Tacoma?

Pair a round of sangria cocktails with a spread of beef and lamb empanadas and eloté gnocchi at Asado, an Argentine chophouse.

Where is the best place for live music or performing arts in Tacoma?

Tacoma Dome is a major venue known for concerts, live performances and sporting events. For something a little more intimate, consider Rialto Theater on 9th downtown.

Where is the best happy hour in Tacoma?

Located in a 1907 historic firehouse, Engine House No. 9 (affectionately known as E9) offers a hearty selection of house-brewed ale, burgers and a stellar happy hour menu.

The Local and State Economy in Tacoma, WA

What are the three largest industries in Tacoma?

Tacoma’s most prominent industries include health care, trade and transportation, and manufacturing. Manufacturing is an essential industry in Tacoma, and several manufacturing companies are located here, including aerospace and defense contractors like Boeing and the Joint Base Lewis-McChord.

What is the sales tax rate in Tacoma?

In 2024, the sales tax rate in Tacoma is 10.3%.

Does Washington have a state income tax?

No, Washington does not have a state income tax.

Who are the major health care providers in Tacoma?

Tacoma has several high-quality hospitals and medical centers, including MultiCare Tacoma General Hospital, Virginia Mason Franciscan Health St. Joseph Medical Center and MultiCare Allenmore Hospital.

What colleges and universities are in Tacoma?

Several colleges and universities are located in Tacoma, including Bates Technical College, Tacoma Community College, the University of Puget Sound, the University of Washington at Tacoma and Pacific Lutheran University.
